newsitem.title: UK: FORECAST - Newsprint, TV costs to hit Mirror.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Newsprint, TV costs to hit Mirror.

text.p: Higher newsprint costs and continuing losses from its LIVE TV cable television venture are likely to depress first half results from Mirror Group, analysts said.
Analysts are forecasting pre-tax profit in a range of 32.5-41.0 million stg when Mirror reports on Wednesday. Pre-tax, pre-exceptional profit totalled 39.0 million in the same period a year ago.
Panmure Gordon's Anthony de Larrinaga said that a 40 percent increase in newsprint prices is likely to add some 20 million stg to costs.
He expects most of the shortfall to be made up by an increase of around 12 million stg in circulation revenue and growth of around five million stg in advertising income.
The group increased the price of its flagship Daily Mirror by 2p to 30p in March, as it sought to offset higher costs.
"The performance should rebound in the second half because of falling newsprint prices and an improvement on the advertising side," de Larrinaga said.
He forecasts first half profit of 32.5 million stg but is expecting the full-year to total 87.6 million.
The first half figures are likely to include some six million stg in losses from LIVE TV, Mirror's local cable television network launched last year.
The company has said it expects LIVE to break even within three years after total start-up costs of 25 million stg.
Mirror Group also owns a 46 percent stake in The Independent broadsheet, which lost a total of 18.9 million stg last year.

De Larrinaga forecasts that Mirror's share of Indepedent losses will be around 2.5 million stg in the first half but said this should be virtually cancelled out by a profit contribution from Scottish TV.
Mirror Group has a holding of almost 20 percent in commercial (ITV) channel Scottish.
